title: U.S. Plans to Open Direct Talks With Iran-Backed Houthis in Yemen
authors: Dion Nissenbaum, Warren P. Strobel, Dion.Nissenbaum Wsj.Com, Warren.Strobel Wsj.Com
content:
WASHINGTON—The Trump administration is preparing to initiate direct talks with Iran-backed Houthi forces in Yemen in an effort to end the four-year-old war , a conflict that has become a volatile front line in the conflict with Tehran , according to people familiar with the plans .
The U.S. is looking to prod Saudi Arabia into taking part in secret talks in Oman with Houthi leaders in an effort to broker a cease-fire in Yemen , according to these people .
The move could open the first significant channel between the Trump administration and the Houthis at a time when fears of a broader regional war are growing .
In 2015 , a few months after the war in Yemen began , top Obama administration envoys met secretly with Houthi rebels for the first time in Oman to press for a cease-fire and release of Americans held by the Yemeni fighters . U.S. officials met with Houthi leaders last December in Sweden during United Nations-led peace talks . But there haven ’ t been any significant direct negotiations since President Trump took office in 2017 , current and former U.S. officials said .
The conflict in Yemen has metastasized from a troubling regional civil war into a volatile international fight pitting Iran-backed Houthi forces against a Saudi-led military coalition supported by the U.S .
The Trump administration views Houthi forces as Iran proxies and says Tehran should be held directly responsible for the routine rocket and drone attacks that Yemeni fighters carry out against Saudi Arabia .
Armed Drones Are a Growing Threat From Rebels in Yemen Yemen ’ s Houthi rebels are using armed drones with startling success . WSJ reporters describe their increasing sophistication and recent confirmed attacks . Illustration : Laura Kammermann
The war in Yemen has generated rare bipartisan opposition in Congress and has fueled concerns in Riyadh and Abu Dhabi that Persian Gulf nations are losing critical support from Washington as tensions with Iran rise .
Under pressure from Congress , the U.S. military has scaled back its limited support for the Saudi-led coalition , which has been accused of recklessly killing thousands of Yemeni civilians with botched airstrikes . In April , Mr. Trump vetoed a bipartisan measure that sought to cut off U.S. military support for the war in Yemen . Congress failed to override the veto , but lawmakers from both parties see the war in Yemen as a serious problem for relations with Riyadh .
Share Your Thoughts Do you think the U.S. can bring an end to the war in Yemen ? Why or why not ? Join the conversation below .
According to the Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project , more than 90,000 Yemenis have died since Houthi militants toppled the country ’ s government in 2015 , triggering a move by Saudi Arabia and a small group of allies to fight to unseat the rebel forces .
Yemen is home to what the U.N. calls the world ’ s worst humanitarian crisis . Famine and cholera are constant threats to millions of Yemenis .
The situation in Yemen has deteriorated considerably in recent weeks , creating new urgency for diplomatic efforts to end a conflict that has pushed millions to the brink of famine .
The United Arab Emirates , Saudi Arabia ’ s most important ally in the Yemen effort , began withdrawing most of its forces from the country in June . Earlier this month , Yemeni forces backed by the U.A.E . launched a surprise military assault on the Saudi-backed government operating out of Aden , creating a rupture between the two Gulf nations .
The U.A.E. ’ s withdrawal and fighting in Aden have fueled new efforts by the U.S. to gain momentum for diplomacy , including the evolving plans to talk directly to the Houthis .
The U.S. talks would be led by Christopher Henzel , a veteran diplomat who became the Trump administration ’ s first ambassador to Yemen in April , according to people familiar with the plans .
The nascent Trump administration initiative is already facing serious hurdles . Last week , Houthi forces appointed an official ambassador to Iran after holding public meetings in Tehran . The move was seen by some as a sign that Houthi opponents of peace talks were trying to derail the efforts .
The Saudi-backed leader of the Yemeni government-in-exile , Abed Rabbo Mansour Hadi , is increasingly viewed in key world capitals as an obstructionist to talks , according to the people familiar with the diplomatic efforts . And key players are actively exploring ways to quickly sideline Mr. Hadi in an effort to get peace talks moving .
There also are simmering concerns in Washington that Saudi Arabia isn ’ t serious about ending the conflict . This week , American officials plan to meet with Saudi leaders in Washington to impress upon them the importance of embracing diplomacy .
Khalid bin Salman , the Saudi vice defense minister and brother of Crown Prince Mohammad bin Salman , was scheduled to meet with Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Wednesday .
A State Department official said the U.S. wouldn ’ t discuss private diplomatic talks , but added that “ the U.S. ambassador to Yemen talks to all Yemenis to further U.S. objectives in the country . ”
Saudi and Yemeni officials as well as Houthi representatives didn ’ t respond to requests for comment .
On Monday , Saudi Arabia and the U.A.E . released a joint statement meant to telegraph their unity and rebut suggestions that the two countries are at odds over the way out of Yemen .
“ They affirm their keenness and full endeavor to preserve the Yemeni nation and the interests , security , stability , independence and territorial integrity of the Yemeni people under the leadership of the legitimate president of Yemen , as well as to counter the coup of the Iranian-backed Houthi terrorist militia and other terrorist organizations , ” the two countries said in the joint statement .
One U.S. official familiar with the matter said the planned backchannel talks reflect a lack of viable military options available to the Saudi-led alliance in Yemen . The official expressed skepticism that they will lead to a breakthrough .
The U.S. has struggled in the past to find Houthi intermediaries who both have authority to negotiate and access to the movement ’ s senior leadership , the official said . One interlocutor has been Mohammed Abdul Salam , the Houthis ’ chief spokesman , with whom U.S. officials have communicated for the previous four years , he said .
The backchannel talks seem certain to involve possible offers of concessions or confidence-building measures to the Iran-aligned Houthis , the official said , adding that could undercut the Trump administration ’ s campaign of “ maximum pressure ” on Tehran and its allies .
The Houthis , whose tribal homelands are in northern Yemen , took over the capital , San ’ a , in 2015 . They now control most of the western half of the country .
Washington has long debated how to deal with the Houthis . Some officials in the White House have argued that they should be designated as a foreign terrorist organization , people familiar with the matter said . Opponents counter that doing so would effectively kill U.N.-sponsored peace talks which so far have failed to secure an end to the war .
The Houthi leadership appears to be split between those who favor continuing the war and those who want to end it , which could further complicate negotiations with the group .
